Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandfather for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story:
I sat on the porch, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My grandson, eyes wide and voice trembling, had just asked me for advice about a fight he’d had with his best friend. He wanted to know what I would do, how I’d handled things when I was his age. I could see how much he needed me to be calm, wise, and present—someone who could help him make sense of his feelings.

But my phone kept vibrating. It was my girlfriend, texting again. We’d argued three times this week about money—how we spent it, how we saved it, how we talked about it. She wanted to talk now, to resolve things before the tension grew any worse. I knew she expected me to be attentive, to listen, to help us find a way forward.

I felt pulled in two directions, my heart heavy. My grandson needed my undivided attention, but so did she. I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing on me, each demanding a different part of myself, and I didn’t know how to be what both of them needed at the same time.
